title: Is there any Chinese language textbook that uses only Pinyin? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my experience, most introductory Chinese textbooks will give you an entirely Pinyin dialogue beside the Chinese character dialogue, and reading practice may also give you interlinear pinyin above the characters or between the character lines. That said, you really should learn characters. Even if you’re 100% sure you just want to learn to speak, you’re going to be utterly lost in pretty much every situation where you’d regularly be speaking Chinese (say, in China!) because you don’t understand the characters. They look daunting, but they’re really not a big deal once you get used to them. If you can learn to recognize the patterns between them and their components, it really is little different from running into a new vocab word while reading in French or German, except that it’s arranged somewhat differently. Improving your reading will also reflect on your speaking, as well. It’s a holistic thing and, beyond a certain point, speaking skills in another language aren't just about grammar and vocab, they're also about cultural knowledge. And Chinese culture is heavily literary. Again, it’s not going to affect you much on a day-to-day basis or when you’re beginning, but eventually you’re probably going to want to actually read things in the language and carry that over to your speaking.

The otherwise pretty good “Mandarin Chinese: A Functional Reference Grammar” by Charles N. Li and Sandra A. Thompson is entirely in Pinyin. However, this is not a textbook, properly speaking, but a reference… though I’d imagine lots of people keep it around when learning how to use de, de, and de (that is, 的, 得, and 地, respectively).
